ch.ecma.csta.voiceunit

Interface VoiceUnitServices

  • All Known Subinterfaces:
    ExtendedVoiceUnitServices

    public interface VoiceUnitServices
    A set of services that allows messages consisting of voice stream data to be played to a media stream as if coming from a device, or recorded from a device's incoming media stream. A Voice Unit is a CSTA special resource function. It can be observed and controlled using the methods provided in this interface. A voice unit device could be used to play a file to a real-time protocol (RTP) stream or record an RTP stream.

    The messages that get played or recorded are stored in files whose directory is configured outside of the API. Playing or recording occurs across multiple calls at a device until a termination criterion is met or until explicitly stopped.

    The supported encoding algorithm types for playing and recording these messages are:

    • Pulse Code Modulation (PCM) 8 bit and 16 bit.
    • G.711 A-law and Mu-law
    • G.729 and G.729A
    The RTP stream encoding algorithm type is used if one is not specified. This is known as the pass through mode.

    The supported conversions between encoding algorithm types are:

    • Conversion from any G.711 type to any PCM or G.711 encoding type
    • Conversion from any PCM type to any G.71 or PCM type
    A message that requires an unsupported conversion cannot be played or recorded. This implies that invoking playMessage or startDubbing will fail in such cases.

    Silence packets are transmitted for the G.711 and PCM encoding algorithm types. No silence packets are transmitted for the G.729 encoding algorithm types.

    All digital audio files that are played or recorded using VoiceUnitServices are in the Wave Resource Interchange File Format (RIFF). The standard Wave file structure is used for all encoded media types. However, since standard Wave does not accomodate G.729 encoding, non-standard G.729 field values are used in some of the format chunk fields. An external G.729 converter is required to convert a G.729 Wave file into a standard RIFF Wave file that can be played.

    A Connection Identifier is used to indicate the call that the Voice Unit relates to a message. Note that in this Avaya implementation of VoiceUnitServices, only the device identifier field in the ConnectionID parameter is needed to play or record a message. The other fields in a connection identifier are not used at this time. Therefore a recording is specific to a device and not to a particular connection at that device. The effect is:

    • If the call ends, the player or recorder will not be stopped automatically. Either a termination condition will have to be satisfied or the application will have to stop the player or the recorder explicitly.
    • If the device is involved in more than one call, then the message will be played to, or recorded from, the active call.

    Voice Unit Services can be used to record some portion of a call or play a message as part of a call.

    A message identifier is the name of the file used to play or record a message. The file can have either have numeric name with a .wav suffix or can have an alphanumeric name with or without a .wav suffix. Either way, the file must be in Wave format.

    Avaya provides extended voice unit services for dubbing, suspending, resuming, and stopping. Dubbing allows a message to replace a portion of a message that is being recorded. See ExtendedVoiceUnitServices.

    Prerequisites Before using voice unit services, do the following:

    1. Get access to VoiceUnitServices through the ServiceProvider. For example: 
       VoiceUnitServices voiceSvcs =
   (VoiceUnitServices)servProv.getService(ch.ecma.csta.voiceunit.VoiceUnitServices.class.getName());
    2. Get a device ID from DeviceServices and gain exclusive control of the device using TerminalServices.
    3. Implement a VoiceUnitListener and add it using MonitoringServices.addVoiceUnitListener so that the application is prepared to catch events before they occur.

    Clean Up When you are finished using VoiceUnitServices, remove any listeners that were added for that device using MonitoringServices.removeVoiceUnitListener().

    Note that not all of the requests and for these services may be supported. In these cases, the request description will state that it is not supported.
    Similarly, not all of the parameters may be supported for a given request, or for any associated events. In these cases, the description of the request (or event) will contain a table of the parameters that are supported.

    Version:
    $Revision: 1.8 $
    Author:
    AVAYA, Inc.
    See Also:
    ExtendedVoiceUnitServices, "ECMA-269, section 26 for voice unit services and event descriptions", "ECMA-323, section 24 for XCSTA schemas of voice unit services and events"

    • Method Detail

      • concatenateMessage

        ConcatenateMessageResponse concatenateMessage(ConcatenateMessage request)
                                       throws CstaException
        Not supported.
        Throws:
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • deleteMessage

        DeleteMessageResponse deleteMessage(DeleteMessage request)
                             throws CstaException
        Deletes a message from the recorded files directory. Files that have been recorded using recordMessage have been stored in the directory specified in the cmapi-user-configuration.properties file in the com.avaya.mvcs.media.VoiceUnitServices.dir.recorder. Files under that directory can be deleted using this deleteMessage method. See the DeleteMessage request for more information.

        Optional parameters can be set in the extensions parameter's CSTACommonArguments private data area with an Avaya-specified DeleteMessagePrivateData object. The parameters that can be set are:

        • filename - Conditional. An alphanumeric filename of a message to be deleted. Include any suffix in the name. May include a subdirectory path that is relative to the path specified in the cmapi-user-configuration.properties file in the com.avaya.mvcs.media.VoiceUnitServices.dir.recorder
        Use CSTACommonArguments.setSinglePrivateData (DeleteMessagePrivateData).

        Parameters:
        request - a request to delete a message in the recorded files directory
        Returns:
        a DeleteMessageResponse which indicates that VoiceUnitServices has accepted and processed the request. The response does not contain any useful information.
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if an invalid parameter is passed
        InvalidFileException - if unable to find the file
        OperationException - if an IOException occurred or if a channel is already closed
        SystemResourceAvailabilityException - if a severe system error like un-availability of a system wide resource
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • playMessage

        PlayMessageResponse playMessage(PlayMessage request)
                         throws CstaException
        Plays one or more audio messages on a particular device. The service may also specify termination conditions, which if encountered, cause message playback to stop. The message(s) to be played must already exist in a Wave file(s) on the connector server. See the PlayMessage request for more information.

        The overConnection parameter specifies the connection on which the message is to be played (note that only the DeviceID field of the ConnectionID is actually used). A DeviceID must be obtained from DeviceServices. See Setting a Connection ID for a coding example of how to set just the DeviceID portion of a ConnectionID. If the device is involved in more than one call, then the message will be played to the active call.

        Optional parameters can be set in the extensions CSTACommonArguments private data area with an Avaya-specified PlayMessagePrivateData object. The parameters that can be set are:

        • playMessage - Optional
        • playCount - Optional
        • playInterval - Optional
        • playList - Optional

        Here is an example of how to set an alphanumeric filename and a count and interval in the extensions parameter: 

         CSTACommonArguments comnArgs = new CSTACommonArguments();
 PlayMessagePrivateData playPrivData = new PlayMessagePrivateData();
 playPrivData.setPlayMessage("Welcome.wav");
 playPrivData.setPlayCount(new Integer(Integer.MAX_VALUE));
 playPrivData.setPlayInterval(new Long(5000));
 comnArgs.setSinglePrivateData(playPrivData);
 PlayMessage request = new PlayMessage();
 request.setExtensions(comnArgs);
        Here is an example of how to specify a file list in the extensions parameter: 
         CSTACommonArguments comnArgs = new CSTACommonArguments();
 PlayMessagePrivateData playPrivData = new PlayMessagePrivateData();
 String[] fileList = new String[2];
 fileList[0] = "Welcome.wav";
 fileList[1] = "Options.wav";
 playPrivData.setFileList(fileList);
 commonArgs.setSinglePrivateData(playPrivData);
 request.setExtensions(comnArgs);

        If you have added one or more VoiceUnitListeners, then the listener's callback methods are called as playback progresses. If there is a problem with the request, an exception is thrown.

        To avoid potential timing problems, a VoiceUnitListener should be added prior to calling the playMessage method. If a listener is added after the playMessage method is called, the listener may, or may not, receive the appropriate event (the event may occur before the listener is added).

        Parameters:
        request - a request to play a voice message on a particular device. Includes name of file(s) to be played, the connection identifier that contains the device identifier, how frequently to replay the message or for what duration the message is to be played, and a list of conditions that will cause the playback to terminate.
        Returns:
        a play message response which indicates that the message(s) is(are) being played
        Throws:
        InvalidConnectionIDException - if unable to find the Media Session associated with the DeviceID of this request
        InvalidFileException - if Audio File format is not supported or if File (messageID) specified is not found
        InvalidMsgIDException - if the specified messageID is invalid or if the File (messageID) is not found
        InvalidParameterValueException - if an invalid parameter is passed
        MessageIDRequiredException - if messageID is null
        NotAbleToPlayException - if an IOException occurs with the Player or Recorder of this Service or if any other error occurs with the Player or Recorder of this Service
        SystemResourceAvailabilityException - if a severe system error like un-availability of a system wide resource
        InvalidObjectStateException - if the player is in an invalid state.
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • queryVoiceAttribute

        QueryVoiceAttributeResponse queryVoiceAttribute(QueryVoiceAttribute request)
                                         throws CstaException
        Not supported.
        Throws:
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • recordMessage

        RecordMessageResponse recordMessage(RecordMessage request)
                             throws CstaException
        Starts recording media stream coming into a specified device. The application can specify a file name to hold the recorded message or the file name can default to <timestamp><extension>.wav, where timestamp is the local start time of the recording and extension is the phone number of the device. Timestamp is formatted as yyyyMMddhhmmss, where
        yyyyis year
        MMis month
        ddis day
        hhis hour
        mmis minutes
        ssis seconds

        See the RecordMessage request for more information.

        The callToBeRecorded parameter specifies the device whose incoming media stream is to be recorded. (only the deviceID field of the connectionID is used). A device ID must be obtained from DeviceServices. See Setting a Connection ID for a coding example of how to set just the device ID portion of a ConnectionID. If the device is involved in more than one call, then the active call will be recorded.

        Optional parameters can be set in the extensions CSTACommonArguments private data area with an Avaya-specified RecordMessagePrivateData object. The parameters that can be set are:

        • encoding - Optional
        • filename - Optional
        Use CSTACommonArguments.setSinglePrivateData (RecordMessagePrivateData). See the contents of RecordMessagePrivateData and example code below.

        The extensions parameter returned in the RecordMessageResponse contains additional data in the parameter's CSTACommonArguments private data area with an Avaya-specified RecordMessageResponsePrivateData object.

        The data that is returned is:

        • filename - Always provided
        • timestamp - Always provided

        Here is an example of how you can specify in the PrivateData area that the Wave file that results from a recording should be in the specified encoding format regardless of the incoming media format: 

         // Request that recording be placed in G.711 Mu-law encoded Wave file.
 CSTACommonArguments comnArgs = new CSTACommonArguments();
 RecordMessagePrivateData recordPrivData = new RecordMessagePrivateData();
 RecordMessage request = new RecordMessage();
 request.setMaxDuration(new Long(60000)); // Record for 60 secs
 recordPrivData.setEncoding(MediaConstants.G711U);
 commonArgs.setSinglePrivateData(recordPrivData);
 request.setExtensions(comnArgs);

        To get the start time out of the RecordMessageResponse extensions parameter, your code may look like this: 

         // Extract the start timestamp and filename from the extensions
 // parameter, RecordMessageResponsePrivateData.
 CSTACommonArguments comnArgs = response.getExtensions();
 RecordMessageResponsePrivateData  responsePrivData =
    (RecordMessageResponsePrivateData) comnArgs.getSinglePrivateData();
 String timestamp = responsePrivData.getTimestamp();
 String filename = response.getResultingMessage();// get numeric filename

 // If numeric filename is "0", then get the alphanumeric filename.
 if(filename.equals("0"))
    filename = responsePrivData.getFilename();

        If you have added one or more VoiceUnitListeners, then the listener's callback methods are called as recording progresses. If there is a problem with the request, an exception is thrown.

        When calling recordMessage and stop multiple times, a StopEvent from an earlier stop may occur after subsequent calls to recordMessage. This means a StopEvent may be associated with an earlier recordMessage rather than the most recent recordMessage.

        To avoid potential timing problems, a VoiceUnitListener should be implemented and added prior to calling the recordMessage method. If a listener is added after the recordMessage method is called, the listener may or may not receive the appropriate event (the event may occur before the listener is added).

        Parameters:
        request - a request to start recording a new message from a specified device. Includes device identifier and termination criteria. Encoding can be set in the extensions' PrivateData.
        Returns:
        the resulting filename where message is stored and a timestamp.
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if an invalid parameter is passed
        InvalidConnectionIDException - if unable to find the Media Session associated with the DeviceID of this request
        InvalidFileException - if File (messageID) Specified is not found or if a Security Exception occurred for the specified File (messageID)
        OperationException - if an IOExceptioncpetion occurred or if a channel is already closed
        SystemResourceAvailabilityException - if a severe system error like un-availability of a system wide resource
        InvalidObjectStateException - if the recorder is in an invalid state
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

                       throws CstaException

        Throws:
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • resume

        ResumeResponse resume(Resume request)
               throws CstaException
        Restarts the playing and recording of previously suspended messages at their current position. See the Resume request for more information.

        Parameters:
        request - a request to restart the playing and recording of a previously suspended messages at their current positions.
        Returns:
        a ResumeResponse indicating that VoiceUnitServices has accepted the request, the request appears valid, and the request is being processed.
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if an invalid parameter is passed
        InvalidConnectionIDException - if unable to find the Media Session associated with the DeviceID of this request
        InvalidMsgIDException - if the specified messageID is invalid or if the File (messageID) is not found
        MessageIDRequiredException - if messageID is null
        OperationException - if an IOException occurred or if a channel is already closed
        SystemResourceAvailabilityException - if a severe system error like un-availability of a system wide resource
        InvalidObjectStateException - if the player or recorder is in an invalid state
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs
        See Also:
        ExtendedVoiceUnitServices.resumePlaying, ExtendedVoiceUnitServices.resumeRecording

               throws CstaException

      • stop

        StopResponse stop(Stop request)
           throws CstaException
        Stops the playing and recording of messages and resets the position pointer to the beginning of the messages. See the Stop request for more information.

        To avoid potential timing problems, a VoiceUnitListener should be implemented and added prior to calling the stop method. If a listener is added after the stop method is called, the listener may or may not receive the appropriate event (the event may occur before the listener is added).

        Parameters:
        request - a request to stop playing and recording messages.
        Returns:
        a StopResponse which indicates that VoiceUnitServices has accepted the request, the request appears valid, and the request is being processed. The response does not contain any useful information.
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if an invalid parameter is passed
        InvalidConnectionIDException - if unable to find the Media Session associated with the DeviceID of this request
        OperationException - if an IOException occurred or if a channel is already closed
        SystemResourceAvailabilityException - if a severe system error like un-availability of a system wide resource
        InvalidObjectStateException - if the player or recorder is in an invalid state
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs
        See Also:
        ExtendedVoiceUnitServices.stopPlaying(), ExtendedVoiceUnitServices.stopRecording()

      • suspend

        SuspendResponse suspend(Suspend request)
                 throws CstaException
        Temporarily stops the playing and recording of the current messages and leaves the position pointers at their current locations. See the Suspend request for more information.

        To avoid potential timing problems, a VoiceUnitListener should be implemented and added prior to calling the suspend method. If a listener is added after the suspend method is called, the listener may or may not receive the appropriate event (the event may occur before the listener is added).

        Parameters:
        request - a request to temporarily stop the playing and recording of the current message.
        Returns:
        a StopResponse indicates that VoiceUnitServices has accepted the request, the request appears valid, and the request is being processed. There is no useful information in the response.
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if an invalid parameter is passed
        InvalidConnectionIDException - if unable to find the Media Session associated with the DeviceID of this request
        OperationException - if an IOException occurred or if a channel is already closed
        SystemResourceAvailabilityException - if a severe system error like un-availability of a system wide resource
        InvalidObjectStateException - if the player or recorder is in an invalid state
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs
        See Also:
        ExtendedVoiceUnitServices.suspendPlaying, ExtendedVoiceUnitServices.suspendRecording

      • synthesizeMessage

                                     throws CstaException

        Throws:
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • addVoiceUnitListener

        void addVoiceUnitListener(DeviceID device,
                          VoiceUnitListener listener)
                   throws CstaException
        Deprecated. Use MonitoringServices.addVoiceUnitListener instead.
        Adds a listener to monitor the specified physical device for voice unit events.

        Voice unit events report changes to the voice stream data messages being recorded and played. In other words, the voice unit events reflect the state changes of a Voice Unit.

        A Voice Unit state is a state that a Voice Unit may take in relating a call with a message. It relates a call to its message in terms of playing, recording, suspending, etc. Voice Units may have several states concurrently with respect to different calls and messages. Voice Unit states are reported by Voice Unit Event Reports. A typical transition model for Voice Unit states is shown in ECMA-269, section 6.2.1, "Voice Unit".

        Java listeners are used to implement the CSTA concept called monitoring. Adding a listener is equivalent to requesting a Monitor Start service.

        When an event occurs, the corresponding listener callback is called. A default callback is provided by VoiceUnitAdapter for each possible event. The default callbacks do nothing. If you want to act upon events, customize the events' callbacks for your application in either of the following ways:

        • Provide an implementation of every callback method in the VoiceUnitListener interface with a class that implements VoiceUnitListener.
        • Provide an implementation of a subset of callback methods with a class that extends VoiceUnitAdapter.

        If multiple listeners are added to a device, then each listener will be notified of events on that device; the corresponding callback will be called on each listener that has been added.

        When you no longer wish to receive Voice Unit events for the device, be sure to remove the Voice Unit listener(s) with removeVoiceUnitListener.

        Parameters:
        device - the device to which the VoiceUnitListener is applied
        listener - the listener being applied to the device. The listener may be an implementation of the VoiceUnitListener interface or an extension of VoiceUnitAdapter. If the specified listener is null, no exception is thrown and no action is performed.
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if an invalid parameter is passed
        SystemResourceAvailabilityException - if a severe system error like un-availability of a system wide resource
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs

      • removeVoiceUnitListener

        void removeVoiceUnitListener(DeviceID device,
                             VoiceUnitListener listener)
                      throws CstaException
        Deprecated. Use MonitoringServices.removeVoiceUnitListener instead.
        Removes a previously specified voice unit listener. It is possible for a callback to be issued on a listener after it has been removed. If no listeners have been added, then nothing happens when an event occurs. This method performs no function, nor does it throw an exception if the specified listener was not previously added. If the specified listener is null, no exception is thrown and no action is performed.
        Parameters:
        device - the device whose VoiceUnitListener is to be removed
        listener - the listener being removed from the device
        Throws:
        InvalidParameterValueException - if an invalid parameter is passed
        SystemResourceAvailabilityException - if a severe system error like un-availability of a system wide resource
        CstaException - if an implementation-specific exception occurs
        See Also:
        addVoiceUnitListener(ch.ecma.csta.binding.DeviceID, ch.ecma.csta.voiceunit.VoiceUnitListener)
